subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Question, How to get the U sound in "Up"?
msgSnippet: Hi Chuck, I m not so sure I did as well with your question as I might have. The schwa I was talking about occurs as the a in ago, the e in agent, the i in
messageBody:
Hi Chuck,

 

I’m not so sure I did as well with your question as I might have.

 

The schwa I was talking about occurs as the a in ago, the e in agent, the i in sanity, the o in comply, and the u in focus. In some dictionaries it is also the u in up. In other dictionaries, a different symbol is used for the u in up. So there is a possible distinction between the two sounds. However, they are close.

 

Quickscript does not distinguish between the two sounds. I believe it uses the same symbol, number 36, for the u sound of up and the a sound in ago. This is apparently not the case for Shavian, which does distinguish the sounds.

 

The following is a copy of 3/16/2002 correspondence on this subject:

 

"C. Paige Gabhart" wrote:
[omitted text]

>
> When Read developed Quikscript, he dropped the two separate characters
for  the
> pairs "Err" and "Array" and "Up" and
"Ado" which appeared in Shavian.  This was
> done after extensive correspondence in Shavian between English
speaking countries
> around the world.  I assume he decided that the distinction was
not as clear as he
> first thought it was from his British perspective, and that it added a
needless
> complexity to the alphabet.  On the other hand, he added
"Wh" to Quikscript, which
> he learned many people still do distinguish and feel quite strongly
about it.
>
> I have not followed the discussion closely regarding stress, but if
that is the
> primary distinction between "Ado" and "Up" and
"Array" and "Err", then I believe
> Read was correct in dropping the "stressed"
characters.  I have been using
> Quikscript for over twenty-five years, and I have never missed
"Err" or "Up".  In
> fact, I was not sure what sounds they were supposed to represent as I
could not
> hear any distinction in the way I pronounced the applicable
words.  It had never
> occurred to me that the difference was supposedly one of stress. 
My reaction is
> that certain vowels will be stressed as a result of where they appear
in a given
> word  and as a result of the consonants surrounding them. 
We do not have other
> letters whose only difference is stress, and I do not think stress
should be
> represented by a different character in the alphabet.
>
> The dictionary I have here at home is Webster's Ninth New
Collegiate.  I looked up
> "Ado", "Up", "Array" and
"Err", and the opening vowel sound of all four words is
> represented by a schwa.  The difference in stress is shown by an
accent, not by a
> different phonetic symbol.  The word "abut", which Hugh
recently mentioned in a
> post as needing "Up", rather than "Ado" for its
second vowel is also listed with a
> schwa.  Thus, I find no reason to suppose that Read somehow
needlessly simplified
> Quikscript's ability to accurately represent English.  And I have
to respectfully
> disagree with you that these are separate and distinct sounds.
>
> > Ado and Up are distinct sounds as are Err and Array.
> > quickscript combines err and array which makes it harder to
express
> > certain things, IMHO.
> >
> > Peace,
> > Star
color=navy face=Arial>

phone:  301 390 5115

 

-----Original Message-----
From: chuck091956 [mailto:chuck091956@...]
Sent: Tuesday, May 14, 2002 8:13 AM
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Question, How to get the U sound in "Up"?

 

Thanks for the reply,

I concidered that but I guess my New Jersey acent did not allow it.
In the charts I've see for that charater, it's shown a "Ado". When I
would say "Ado" and "Ash" (both sounding like "at")I could not hear
any difference.

Thanks for the clarification,
Chuck

--- In Read_Alphabet@y..., "Ed Gaddy" <ed.gaddy@e...> wrote:

> Hi Chuck,
>
> I'm not sure I understand your question, but the "u" sound
in up is
> represented by the 36th letter in Quickscript. This letter is the
arc
> described by the upper left quadrant of a circle. If you have Jerome
> installed on your keyboard it is obtained by pressing lower case a.
>
> The sound is called a schwa and is frequently represented by an
upside down
> e as in the International Phonetic Alphabet.
>
> If you have Jerome installed on your computer and if your e-mail
program can
> take fonts, you can see "u" sound below:
>
> a
>
> Your name is spelled:
>
> cak
>
> gUd wiSes
>
> ed
>
> e-mail: ed.gaddy@e...
> phone:  301 390 5115
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: chuck091956 [mailto:chuck091956@y...]
> Sent: Monday, May 13, 2002 6:18 PM
> To: Read_Alphabet@y...
> Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Question, How to get the U sound in
"Up"?
>
> Hello All,
>
> Maybe I'm missing it or my acent if messing me up, but how do you
get
> the "u" sound like in the word "up"?
>
> Help,
> Chuck
>
